patient_information: Age: 40 years Sex: female Travel history: recent travel to north-east Thailand one week prior; visited friends and relatives, consumed traditional regional dishes including freshwater fish, seafood, snails, and frogs Symptoms onset: severe headache for the past 8 days Comorbidities: unremarkable Allergies: none
chief_complaint: Acute severe headache of gradual onset for approximately one week.
history_of_present_illness: The patient presented with a history of severe headache that began shortly after returning from a trip to north-east Thailand. The symptoms included fever, myalgias, retro-orbital pain, and a maculopapular rash. Symptoms progressed over the course of one week.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: recent travel to rural Thailand Vector exposures: mosquito exposure implied by the endemic setting Animal exposures: no animal exposures reported Water food risks: no water or food risks reported Contacts: no sick contacts reported Season outbreak context: travel to an endemic area
vitals: Temperature: maximum recorded temperature 39.5 Â°C Other vitals: not reported
physical_exam: Skin: maculopapular rash Heent: retro-orbital discomfort Chest: no focal neurologic deficits or respiratory distress described Abdo: no subcutaneous swellings Neuro: no cranial nerve palsies, no rash, no oral thrush Lymph: no lymphadenopathy
labs_and_diagnostics: Cbc: not reported Key chem coag: not reported Inflammatory markers: not reported Microbiology serology pcr: Dengue NS1 antigen positive on day 2, no imaging was reported
differential_diagnosis: Considered: ["dengue fever versus chikungunya and malaria", "dengue supported by NS1 positivity, thrombocytopenia, and travel to an endemic area; malaria less likely given dengue confirmation and no malaria-specific findings reported"]
management_and_clinical_course: Supportive care: oral/IV fluids and acetaminophen Antimicrobials: no antibiotics prescribed Clinical improvement: full recovery by day 6; no complications documented
final_diagnosis: Disease name short: Dengue fever Causative agent confirmation method: confirmed by a positive NS1 antigen test Evidence: acute febrile illness, thrombocytopenia, retro-orbital pain, and compatible travel exposure
